column4: So far consensus: Primary term Image data, exact synonym Image, meaning image or a set of (related) images (forming e.g. a stack or a time-lapse). No synonyms for stacks and "movies", these should be specialised concepts.
Information, represented in an information artefact (data record) that is 'understandable' by dedicated computational tools that can use the data as input or produce it as output.
column50: Information, represented in an information artefact (data record) that is 'understandable' by dedicated computational tools that can use the data as input or produce it as output.

column4:
A (2D) image is the optical counterpart of an object produced by an optical or an electronic device.

A (2D) digital image is a representation of a real (2D) image in a form of a 2D array, or matrix, containing numbers that can be stored and handled by a digital computer.|wikipedia has a poor definition of an image|For each pixel, the imaging device records a number, or a small set of numbers, that describe some property of this pixel, such as its brightness (the intensity of the light) or its color. 
Numbers in a matrix are responses from a sensor measured at a set of sampling points, arranged into rows and columns. Digital image is a union of pixels - picture elements - assigned to sampling points. Pixels are typically square regions centered at a sampling point.
column50:
A (2D) image is the optical counterpart of an object produced by an optical or an electronic device.

A (2D) digital image is a representation of a real (2D) image in a form of a 2D array, or matrix, containing numbers that can be stored and handled by a digital computer.

column4: Resolving the discussion on "object vs region vs region of interest", after adding Wiki def. Object is a region, but region can be more than an object.

Synthetically increasing the multiplicity and diversity of data available without collecting new data. Data augmentation relies on a priori knowledge (e.g. of system invariants or the noise structure of the data) to generate more data, typically for training learning models. Common data augmentation techniques include corruption by artificial noise, cropping, padding, rotation, and flipping.
column50: Synthetically increasing the multiplicity and diversity of data available without collecting new data. Data augmentation relies on a priori knowledge (e.g. of system invariants or the noise structure of the data) to generate more data, typically for training learning models. Common data augmentation techniques include corruption by artificial noise, cropping, padding, rotation, and flipping.

column4: Image-to-image translation is a class of image processing techniques where the goal is to learn the mapping between an input image and an output image. It can be applied to a wide range of applications, such as collection style transfer, imaging modality transfer, object transfiguration, season transfer and photo enhancement.
column50: Image-to-image translation is a class of image processing techniques where the goal is to learn the mapping between an input image and an output image. It can be applied to a wide range of applications, such as collection style transfer, imaging modality transfer, object transfiguration, season transfer and photo enhancement.

column3: Transformation into frequency domain|Fast Fourier transform|Wavelet transform|FFT
column4:
Transformation into frequency domain is applicable within signal processing in general, not only within image processing.|Frequency domain analysis (or spectral density estimation), is the process of decomposing a complex signal into simpler parts. Many physical processes are best described as a sum of many individual frequency components. Any process that quantifies the various amounts (e.g. amplitudes, powers, intensities, or phases), versus frequency can be called spectrum analysis.

The Fourier transform of a function produces its frequency spectrum by decomposing the function into its sine and cosine components.

Whereas  the standard Fourier transform is only localized in frequency, wavelets are localized in both time and frequency. Wavelets are handcrafted to correlate with particular frequencies in a signal; a set of wavelets is usually used for a complete analysis.
Image fusion is the process of gathering all the important information from multiple images, and their inclusion into fewer images, usually a single one.
column50: Image fusion is the process of gathering all the important information from multiple images, and their inclusion into fewer images, usually a single one.

column50: Top-hat transform is a morphological operation computed by subtracting the opened image from the original input image. It is used to extract small elements and details from given images.

column4:
Clustering (or cluster analysis) is a process of grouping a set of data points (objects) in such a way that objects in the same group (forming a cluster) are, in some sense,  more similar to each other than to those in other groups (clusters).

Clustering is sometimes referred to as unsupervised classification.
column50:
Clustering (or cluster analysis) is a process of grouping a set of data points (objects) in such a way that objects in the same group (forming a cluster) are, in some sense,  more similar to each other than to those in other groups (clusters).

Clustering is sometimes referred to as unsupervised classification.

Image analysis is a process of extraction of meaningful quantitative or qualitative information from (digital) images, by means of digital image processing techniques, typically using computers.
column50: Image analysis is a process of extraction of meaningful quantitative or qualitative information from (digital) images, by means of digital image processing techniques, typically using computers.

column4: Closing is a morphological operation comprising an erosion followed by a dilation, that is typically used to remove small isolated holes from an image.
column50: Closing is a morphological operation comprising an erosion followed by a dilation, that is typically used to remove small isolated holes from an image.

column4: Dilation is a morphological operation which expands the shapes contained in the input image based on analysis of how (a centre of) a given structuring element hits, or misses the shape.|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dilation_(morphology)
column50: Dilation is a morphological operation which expands the shapes contained in the input image based on analysis of how (a centre of) a given structuring element hits, or misses the shape.|https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dilation_(morphology)

column4:
Distance transform (distance map or distance field) of a (binary) image, w.r.t. an object in the image, transforms the input image into a representation (another image) so that each pixel is assigned its distance to the (closest) object pixel.

Signed distance transform assigns, to each pixel, its distance to the object boundary; background pixels are assigned positive distance values, whereas foreground pixels are assigned negative distance values.
column50:
Distance transform (distance map or distance field) of a (binary) image, w.r.t. an object in the image, transforms the input image into a representation (another image) so that each pixel is assigned its distance to the (closest) object pixel.

Signed distance transform assigns, to each pixel, its distance to the object boundary; background pixels are assigned positive distance values, whereas foreground pixels are assigned negative distance values.

column4: Relation with Edge detection...

Erosion is a morphological operation used to analyse how a (simple) pre-defined probe (called structuring element) fits or misses the shapes in the image.

Grey scale erosion computed in an image point is the minimum of the intensities of the points in its neighborhood, where the neighborhood is defined by the structuring element.
column50:
Erosion is a morphological operation used to analyse how a (simple) pre-defined probe (called structuring element) fits or misses the shapes in the image.

Grey scale erosion computed in an image point is the minimum of the intensities of the points in its neighborhood, where the neighborhood is defined by the structuring element.

column4: Image enhancement is a term used to refer to an operation that increases the quality of the image, being historically more used in the context of contrast enhancement (which improves visualization for the human eye). However, image enhancement is also a very general term that refers to operations that enhance features interest in the image. An image enhancement operation moves further away from the "reality", as opposed to Image reconstruction that moves closer to the "reality".

Image registration is the process of aligning, by applying geometric transformation, two or more misaligned images of the same (or similar) scene, when images are captured under variable conditions that can change the camera perspective or the content of the scene.|Registration is necessary in order to be able to compare or integrate the data obtained from different sensors/imaging modalities, at different times, from different view points, etc.

Registration can  be based on correspondence established between the landmarks or feature points. Alternatively, some similarity/distance metric is established between the image intensity maps to navigate the registration process.
column50: Image registration is the process of aligning, by applying geometric transformation, two or more misaligned images of the same (or similar) scene, when images are captured under variable conditions that can change the camera perspective or the content of the scene.

Mathematical morphology is a theory and technique for the analysis and processing of geometrical structures, based on set theory, lattice theory, topology, and random functions. MM is most commonly applied to digital images, but it can be employed as well on graphs, surface meshes, solids, and many other spatial structures.

Topological and geometrical continuous-space concepts such as size, shape, convexity, connectivity, and geodesic distance, were introduced by MM on both continuous and discrete spaces. MM is also the foundation of morphological image processing, which consists of a set of operators that transform images according to the above characterizations.

The basic morphological operators are erosion, dilation, opening and closing.
column50:
Mathematical morphology is a theory and technique for the analysis and processing of geometrical structures, based on set theory, lattice theory, topology, and random functions. MM is most commonly applied to digital images, but it can be employed as well on graphs, surface meshes, solids, and many other spatial structures.

Topological and geometrical continuous-space concepts such as size, shape, convexity, connectivity, and geodesic distance, were introduced by MM on both continuous and discrete spaces. MM is also the foundation of morphological image processing, which consists of a set of operators that transform images according to the above characterizations.

The basic morphological operators are erosion, dilation, opening and closing.

column4:
Spectroscopy refers to the study of how radiated energy and matter interact. The energy is absorbed by the matter, creating an excited state. The interaction creates some form of electromagnetic waves (EM), often in the form of visible light, such as sparks.

Spectrometry deals with the measurement of a specific spectrum; essentially the application of spectroscopy so that there are quantifiable results that can then be assessed.
column50:
Spectroscopy refers to the study of how radiated energy and matter interact. The energy is absorbed by the matter, creating an excited state. The interaction creates some form of electromagnetic waves (EM), often in the form of visible light, such as sparks.

Spectrometry deals with the measurement of a specific spectrum; essentially the application of spectroscopy so that there are quantifiable results that can then be assessed.

column4: In scanning electron microscopy, a focused beam of electrons is raster scanned over the surface of the sample. The image is typically formed by detecting secondary electrons or backscattered electrons.

column4: imaging of samples in conditions that keeps them alive, allowing the study of dynamic changes.

column4: Phase contrast microscopy is based on the conversion of sample-induced phase shift of light into contrast in an image.

column4: CT is usually understood as X-ray CT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-ray_computed_tomography redirecting to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CT_scan). On the other hand, Optical tomography can also be CT, see concept Optical projection tomography with its synonyms.
Imaging of a thin specimen by a focused electron beam which is scanned over the sample.
column50: Imaging of a thin specimen by a focused electron beam which is scanned over the sample.

column4: A category denoting a rather broad domain or field of interest, of study, application, work, data, or technology. Topics have no clearly defined borders between each other.
column50: A category denoting a rather broad domain or field of interest, of study, application, work, data, or technology. Topics have no clearly defined borders between each other.

column4: Any form of microscopy that uses a beam of accelerated electrons to image a sample. Electron microscopes can image at higher resolution than light microscopy due to the smaller de Broglie wavelength of the electrons.
column50: Any form of microscopy that uses a beam of accelerated electrons to image a sample. Electron microscopes can image at higher resolution than light microscopy due to the smaller de Broglie wavelength of the electrons.

column4: Light microscopy regroups all techniques in microscopy using light to illuminate and produce an image of a sample.|a list of technique to add is to be found here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1amTDpRLmoER8pA4IlGMChFfTHzHmMCFcaqUA1xQBd3k/edit
column50: Light microscopy regroups all techniques in microscopy using light to illuminate and produce an image of a sample.

column4: Technique using magnetic fields and radio waves to generate images of organs.
column50: Technique using magnetic fields and radio waves to generate images of organs.

column4: Statistical learning may either be considered as exact or narrow synonym (or even closely related) synonym of ML. On Wikipedia, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_learning redirects to ML.

column50: Techniques in microscopy based on the use of fluorescent molecules that emit light upon excitation.

column4: In simple terms, high-content screening (HCS) is the combination of high-throughput screening (HTS) applied to high-content analysis (HCA).
